meanings.def: money that somebody invests in a company
examples: a 20 per cent stake in the business
a controlling/majority/minority stake
IBM will take an 18 per cent ownership stake in the new company.
She acquired a 4 per cent direct stake in the company.

meanings.def: a part or share in a business, plan, etc. that will bring you money or other benefits if it succeeds
examples: She has a personal stake in the success of the play.
Many young people no longer feel they have a stake in society.
He has a personal stake in the outcome of the war.

meanings.def: something that you risk losing, especially money, when you try to predict the result of a race, game, etc., or when you are involved in an activity that can succeed or fail
examples: How much was the stake (= how much did you bet)?
They were playing cards for high stakes (= a lot of money).
With only two points separating the top five players, the stakes are high as they enter the final round.
They always play for high stakes.
The political stakes are high.

meanings.def: a wooden or metal post that is pointed at one end and pushed into the ground in order to support something, mark a particular place, etc.
examples: Tall plants can be secured by tying them to stakes.
He was hammering stakes into the ground.
The plants are supported with stout stakes.
The route was marked with stakes with red stripes painted on them.

meanings.def: a wooden post that somebody could be tied to in former times before being burnt to death (= killed by fire) as a punishment
examples: Joan of Arc was burnt at the stake.

meanings.def: the money that is paid to the winners in horse racing
used in the names of some horse races
that can be won or lost, depending on the success of a particular action
examples: We cannot afford to take risks when people's lives are at stake.
The prize at stake is a place in the final.
With so much at stake, we can't afford to make mistakes.
He will face the investigation with his reputation at stake.

meanings.def: to be prepared to do anything in order to defend your opinions or beliefs
examples: He would have gone to the stake for his belief in his daughter’s innocence.

meanings.def: used to say how much of a particular quality a person has, as if they were in a competition in which some people are more successful than others
examples: John doesn't do too well in the personality stakes.
She was determined to win in the fashion stakes.

meanings.def: to suddenly move from your house and go to live somewhere else
examples: He pulled up stakes and went back to France.

idioms.def: that can be won or lost, depending on the success of a particular action
examples: We cannot afford to take risks when people's lives are at stake.
The prize at stake is a place in the final.
With so much at stake, we can't afford to make mistakes.
He will face the investigation with his reputation at stake.

idioms.idiom: go to the stake over/for something
idioms.def: to be prepared to do anything in order to defend your opinions or beliefs
examples: He would have gone to the stake for his belief in his daughter’s innocence.

idioms.def: used to say how much of a particular quality a person has, as if they were in a competition in which some people are more successful than others
examples: John doesn't do too well in the personality stakes.
She was determined to win in the fashion stakes.

idioms.def: to suddenly move from your house and go to live somewhere else
examples: He pulled up stakes and went back to France.

meanings.def: to risk money or something important on the result of something
examples: He staked £25 on the favourite (= for example, in horse racing).
She staked her political career on tax reform, and lost.
That's him over there—I'd stake my life on it (= I am completely confident).

meanings.def: to support something with a stake
examples: to stake newly planted trees
The young trees should be staked after planting.

meanings.def: to say or show publicly that you think something should be yours
examples: Adams staked his claim for a place in the Olympic team with his easy win yesterday.

idioms.def: to say or show publicly that you think something should be yours
examples: Adams staked his claim for a place in the Olympic team with his easy win yesterday.
